posts.name: Abhinav Pidaparthi
posts.cooked:
Hi!

We are using two krakens to power a rotating shooter that also doubles as a climbing mechanism for us. We have recently tested the climbing mechanism, and our robot is able to get off the ground, and stay there, but only when our driver manually controls the arm and keeps it from falling. Once we disable the robot, the robot falls back to the floor. We tried enabling brake mode on Phoenix Tuner X, and although it is better, it still falls back to the ground after it is disabled. We were wondering if there is a way to fix this, preferably in the code, and stop the robot from falling, even after it is disabled. We saw options to tune the PID of the motor in Phoenix Tuner, but were not sure how to do that.

We are using the base WCP SS Rotation Gearbox for each motor, and use a 9 tooth to a 66 tooth sprocket. Please let me know if you have any other questions about these details.

Thanks!

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: You can’t hold it with a PID controller while the robot is disabled. If brake mode isn’t sufficient, you’ll have to adjust gearing or find another way to keep the arm from falling

posts.name: Abhinav Pidaparthi
posts.cooked: Ok, thanks for the help! Are there any other ways to prevent it from falling other than adjusting gearing, since we might not be able to do it in time for our competition.

posts.name: Rishi Desai
posts.cooked: We used a pneumatic ratcheting mechanism last year to keep one of our arms from being affected by the force of gravity. It might be a little to late for this solution as well but just something to keep in mind for the future. You could also try devising your own locking mechanism

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
pvsabhinav:

We tried enabling brake mode on Phoenix Tuner X, and although it is better, it still falls back to the ground after it is disabled.

Just to clarify, since lots of people don’t know. Brake mode effectively “short circuits” the motors, which causes them to resist motion. However, if there is no motion, such as when you are trying to statically hang, there is no force actively preventing the motor from moving. The slow fall you see is an equilibrium of the force of gravity and the resistive force from brake mode.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: In this vein, you could also (depending on your geometry), use surgical tubing or the like pretty easily. Keep in mind that for a climb to count, it only needs to stay up for 5 seconds after being disabled

posts.name: Abhinav Pidaparthi
posts.cooked: Ok, thanks! We will look into it.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: We have very similar thing and we use one-way ratchet on the axle. The downside - once you start climbing, there is no going back But works well for us.
